title: FirstFT: Dealmaking surges past $5.8tn to highest levels on record
text:
How closely did you follow the news this year? Take our 2021 quiz.

Global mergers and acquisitions for 2021 have soared to their highest levels since records began more than four decades ago, thanks in part to booming markets and widespread stimulus measures.

Deals worth more than $5.8tn were agreed worldwide this year, according to figures from Refinitiv, a 64 per cent rise from last year and the fastest pace of growth since the mid-1990s. The value of deals was 54 per cent higher than in 2019 before the pandemic.

It marks out 2021 as an exceptionally busy year, even for an industry that has been accelerating for much of the past decade.

“In 2021 the stars aligned and virtually everything that could go right for [dealmaking] did,” said Frank Aquila, head of M&A at law firm Sullivan & Cromwell.

The M&A boom also contributed to record-breaking fees for investment banks, which totalled $157bn in 2021, including $47bn in fees for M&A advice, the most since records began more than two decades ago.

Three more stories in the news

1. US will respond ‘decisively' if Russia invades Ukraine President Joe Biden told Vladimir Putin that the US and its allies were prepared to respond “decisively” should Russia invade Ukraine. The two leaders spoke for just under an hour in an attempt to defuse tensions as Russia amasses roughly 100,000 troops on Ukraine's eastern frontier.

  • Go deeper What are Putin's military options for Ukraine? Our Moscow correspondent Max Seddon spoke to military experts.

2. 3G Capital buys majority stake in Hunter Douglas 3G Capital, the New York-based private equity group, has acquired a majority of Dutch window coverings manufacturer Hunter Douglas at a valuation of $7.1bn. The deal is the 3G's first major transaction since 2015 when it combined Kraft and Heinz.

3. Maxwell's lawyers begin work on appeal Lawyers for Ghislaine Maxwell said last night they were working on an appeal after the former British socialite was convicted on five of six criminal charges, including sex trafficking. But, facing as much as 65 years in prison, she could conclude it is in her interest to co-operate with authorities trying to charge others involved in Jeffrey Epstein's “pyramid scheme” of sexual abuse.

Coronavirus digest

  • Twenty countries spanning four continents have reported record-breaking numbers of Covid-19 cases in the past week, highlighting the strain Omicron is exerting on health systems worldwide.

  • Cathay Pacific has halted all long-haul cargo flights for a week after Hong Kong tightened its quarantine restrictions for air crew, prompting the carrier to warn of “dramatic disruptions” to the city's supply of essential goods.

  • Two doses of the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine cut the risk of hospitalisation by up to 85 per cent, according to a South African study.

  • What comes after Omicron? Science editor Clive Cookson spoke to a number of medical experts about the virus and what lies ahead in 2022.

What else we're reading

Forecasting the world in 2022 FT writers share their predictions for the new year, from the possible emergence of an even more infectious strain of coronavirus to the Ukraine stand-off and the NFT bubble.

Hertz rebirth delivers $3bn windfall to two backers Little-known investment groups Certares and Knighthead are reaping huge rewards from one of the hedge fund industry's most lucrative trades of 2021, after helping drive the century-old car hire pioneer's exit from bankruptcy.

How NFTs became a $40bn market in 2021 Back in January, only a niche group of crypto enthusiasts knew what non-fungible tokens were. By the end of the year, almost $41bn had been spent on NFTs, making the market for digital artwork and collectibles almost as valuable as the global art market.

Our most-read Weekend article of the year

In February, Yuval Noah Harari looked back at a year of “scientific breakthroughs” and “political failures”, seeking lessons from the Covid-19 pandemic. Read one of our most popular stories of 2021 from the author of Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind:

“Fighting the epidemic is important, but is it worth destroying our freedom in the process? It is the job of politicians rather than engineers to find the right balance between useful surveillance and dystopian nightmares”  — Yuval Noah Harari
